Leaders of principle should have no problem condemning this violence, and pushing back against divisive rhetoric and the tolerance of violence in our politics.
Anyone who cares about violence in our streets, about the health of our democracy, about the rise of racism, bigotry and extremist groups in our country should find this disturbing.

Thousands of protesters, including members of the Proud Boys, marched in the streets of our nation‚Äôs capital, called for the overturn of a free & fair election, engaged in violence, injured police officers, tore Black Lives Matter signs from churches & burned them in the streets.

I had chills watching the first trucks head out with the vaccine.

As Michiganders, we don‚Äôt often brag, but responding to a generational crisis by stepping up and getting things done is something we should all be proud of.

When the country needed ventilators, GM and Ford stepped up to make them. And now, when the country is looking for a light at the end of the tunnel, we are making and shipping the first doses of the vaccine.

It‚Äôs possible because here in Michigan we make things and build things.

When our country desperately needed access to medical supplies, our companies used their supply chains to get ahold of them ‚Äî and MI manufacturers large and small retooled to make their own, helping to keep our communities going in the tough, early months of this crisis.

This crisis has hit our state hard. But through it all, we have turned our resilience, grit and determination as Michiganders into leading the country down the path out of this crisis.

I simply could not be prouder of our state. https://www.freep.com/story/news/health/2020/12/13/pfizer-covid-19-vaccines-kalamazoo-michigan/6529215002/
